Key theories related to human memory and recall include:

1. Atkinson-Shiffrin Model: This model proposes that information first enters our sensory memory, then moves to our working memory, and finally moves into long-term memory for retrieval.

2. Levels of Processing Model: This model proposes that the depth of processing impacts the likelihood of information being stored in long-term memory. Memory is enhanced by processing information at a deeper level.

3. Encoding Specificity Principle: This principle proposes that memory retrieval is best when the environmental cues present during retrieval match the cues present during encoding.

4. Consolidation Theory: This theory proposes that new memories are consolidated in the brain during sleep.

Common strategies for enhancing memory retention include:

1. Repetition: Rehearsing information multiple times can help to encode it in long-term memory.

2. Chunking: Breaking down information into smaller, manageable chunks can help make it easier to remember.

3. Mnemonic Devices: These are memory aids that help us remember information through the use of acronyms, rhymes, or other associations.

4. Visual Imagery: Creating mental images of information can help to recall it later on.

5. Spaced Learning: Practicing information over several short sessions spaced out over time can improve long-term retention compared to practicing all at once.
